reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s relatively optimistic pathway to mostly-great futures via partial AM-convergence plus trade/compromise (section 3), arguing that the assumed stable separability/implementability of bargains is unrealistic once interacting value-systems generate institutional dynamics and drift. This is a meaningful hit to one of the essay’s main proposed optimism channels, but not fully central because the essay already flags multiple blockers (threats, institutions, power concentration, timing) and treats the “galaxy split” as illustrative rather than required. The critique’s argument is suggestive but largely generic: it asserts ‘complex adaptive system’ unpredictability and dynamic instability without showing that (a) the relevant trade equilibria can’t be made robust with enforcement/contracting, (b) partitioning truly requires strong interaction, or (c) unpredictability implies systematically low value rather than just variance. Several claims are plausible (institutional drift, emergent dynamics), but the stronger phrasing (“fundamentally unpredictable from initial conditions,” “clean separation…dynamically unstable”) is overconfident and under-argued. It is reasonably clear and focused, with modest jargon but little outright filler.
title: Moral trade boundaries create unpredictable emergent dynamics that destabilize clean separation
